page.title: 04Draining Tetchill Moor
page.content: In the 17th. century, a man called Gosse noted that, prior to enclosure, the moor was "a great waste of mosse and morishe ground overflowed with water and overgrown with alders and underwoods of no value". He noted that a spear stuck into it would find no bottom but, once enclosed, bits on the edge had turned into good meadow. He decided to dig a ditch to drain and lease the land and thus improved 450 out of 730 acres of land. A second phase saw French prisoners of war building a conduit at Hordley so that the Tetchill Brook could drain much of the remaining moor. Today drainage and land improvement continues with local firms specialising in construction of mole drain systems so that farmers can improve grassland. In some areas, such as Hordley wharf,conservationists wish to preserve the wetlands.
